My Review:

I like it. 

The pacing is faster than OG Titanquest but slower than Path Of Exile/D2 etc (I like this). 

I think there's a surprising depth of build customization from this system, which seems frontally similar to how Pillars of Eternity handled abilities.  

They do ACTUALLY mean Early Access, as the current available content (11/09/2025) extends to what I think is the end of "Act 2" and there are a decent number of graphical bugs and things like equipment sometimes failing to pull text from the string ID it's trying to draw from. 

Respeccing is available and feels fairly priced, albeit seeming more expensive on the "stats" side of it. Skill respecs are low-cost for the most part. 

Review Score: 8/10. 

I think when refined and expanded this score will elevate to an 8.5 or a 9. Incorporated in this score is SOME implicit expectation of improvement (with bug resolution and expansion of storyline content expanding playtime being where most of the implicit expectation is), but there's a lot of room for additional elevation aside from that and I do think that the devs actually... enjoy gaming and understand player-focused design pretty well.  

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Additional notes on my experience:

I feel that abilities are decently customizable and that what they've done is pretty clever in terms of meaningful build diversity. I utilized Elementalist (EarthFire + ColdLightning masteries) and I felt that there were a lot of directions to take with that build. I feel like barrier, meaty-tanking, and skilldodge were all reasonable defensive avenues. I feel like there are good mono-element builds much more focused on individual casts and that I can find favorable synergy between a lot of stuff. 

In my case used central themes of (Spells), (Mana Reservation), and (Many Skill Hits) to have good general killing power while also being able to activate 150 Amplify Tempest nukes that deal a LOT of damage. The (Many Skill Hits) are mostly relevant to Tempest alone, and I do consider it the "Ult" of this build that can fire once every 10ish seconds. I do utilize the "discharge" ability as another good sustained single-target DPS ability.

I did get smoked from time to time. Most deaths felt fair to the point where I was like "yep my poison resist sucks" or "yup I failed to see/avoid the obvious telegraphed thing". Game is an interesting mix of "not THAT hard" with "consistently threatening".

I just picked what I wanted and ran with it and the build felt pretty strong. It was nice that it went this way, and I did think about macro themes and synergy a lot while playing.

Titan Quest 2 is a Classic-style ARPG game with the ability to design your own character class through the diverse mastery system as you face off against beasts and gods straight out of Greek Mythology.. The story is surprisingly really good and I found myself drawn in and not only wanting to know what happens next but speculating about what's going on behind the scenes and looking for any hints inside the game itself, and the gameplay feels absolutely phenomenal. I am a huge ARPG fan, and while I got into TQ1 late (after Grim Dawn and the Diablo franchise) and I've put in ~500 hours into Last Epoch, my 116 hours spent in this Early Access has been the most enjoyable ARPG experience overall.

Pros:
[list]
[*]The Mastery system gives you far more customization than a standard class system from other ARPG games like Torchlight 2 or Diablo 2. The game currently has 4 masteries, with a 5th coming soon, and that alone gives us 6 unique combinations, 4 "pure" classes, and the "Unblessed" where you don't pick a mastery at all for a challenge run. The 5th mastery will bring that to 10 unique combinations and 5 "pure" classes.
[*]The story is quite engaging and, while a bit cliche at times, has a lot of potential hidden in the background lore if you know where to look. On top of that, the writing for the side quests and characters is quite impressive and makes them quite enjoyable. One lore note actually brought me to tears, which I wasn't expecting at all.
[*]The game is designed in such a way that any class combination can be played in any playstyle. Want to play Elementalist (Storm/Earth) as a melee frontliner and heavy armor instead of a caster? Go for it. Want to play Battlemage (Warfare/Earth) as an archer, picking off his targets with arrows and fire? Go for it. Want to play Stormblade (Rogue/Storm) as a pure caster, shocking your enemies with lightning and freezing them with ice? You can do it! There's really no limitation other than what damage types your specific mastery combination provides.
[*]The soundtrack and visuals are both fantastic, even with the visuals on low for the Steam Deck it still looks great. But seriously, the soundtrack is amazing.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
[*]To get this out of the way first.... Yes, performance is not great right now. The developers are aware and have mentioned that they have some candidates in mind that could improve performance but their focus is on adding more content for now and optimizations are mid to long term goal. That being said, 110 of my 116 hours have been played entirely on the Steam Deck getting 25-30 FPS on average with rare dips to the 18-20 FPS range, so as long as your PC isn't on par with a Steam Deck, you should be perfectly fine to get 30 FPS at the very least, just don't expect an older system to get 90+ FPS on Ultra Settings.
[*]With that caveat out of the way, again this is early access so the content [b][b]is[/b][/b] limited. At the time of writing, we have two chapters that cover what other ARPGs consider an "Act" (same location and enemy types with a final major boss at the end before transitioning to a new area). The Prologue + Chapter 1 took me ~10 hours on this recent playthrough with maybe an hour spent AFK, and now I'm approaching 18-19 hours nearing the end of Chapter 2 with another hour or so spent AFK, note that I clear the whole map on every playthrough. That means that for one character you can expect ~22-23 hours of gameplay, I clearly have around 5x that because I play more than one character.
[/list]

Neutral:
[list]
[*]This game is not a seasonal ARPG. I would personally consider this a pro, but I know people love their seasons. The devs have confirmed that this game will never be a seasonal ARPG as they wanted to capture the enjoyment and replayability of classic ARPGs like Diablo 2, Titan Quest, and Grim Dawn. Yes, I know Diablo 2 has a seasonal ladder, but it's not "seasonal" like PoE or Last Epoch are with seasonal gimmicks/themes, or at least it wasn't.
[*]No Mounts: Again, I consider this a pro, but some people love their mounts. The devs confirmed again that this game will never have mounts. Do with that knowledge what you will.
[*]No Mastery Respecs: I consider this a pro, I like my games to have some permanency of choice. Some people are really upset about this, I get it. So if this is important to you, understand that your mastery choices [b][b]are your class!!![/b][/b] Not a single ARPG on the market lets you change classes mid playthrough, Titan Quest 2 works the same way. If you really care, you can edit your character save files with a tool to change the masteries.
[*]Lastly, the multiplayer is not ready yet. I'm listing this as a neutral because many people are really wanting to play with their friends, and I get it, but you will be able to on release and the devs didn't even want to have the multiplayer available when Early Access launched, but they did because they knew people wanted to try it. It's in a heavily "work-in-progress" state, so it's got major bugs and issues.
[/list]

Overall: The game is fantastic, even in this early state, and I can see myself playing for years to come. That being said, I would only recommend it to people who understand what "Early Access" means and want to help the game improve through surveys, feedback, bug reports, and suggestions.

After several hours with Titan Quest II, I can say the immersion is excellent. The environments, the Mediterranean coastlines and villages are gorgeous.  The quality of the scenery is so high that it genuinely made me want to go to Greece and swim in the Aegean Sea. 
The level design is very well done: there is almost no pointless backtracking, quests flow naturally, and the difficulty and enemy distribution feel very well tuned. The narrative is always present without feeling heavy, and the light altar puzzles add an extra layer of gameplay without breaking the pace of combat. The soundtrack is also sublime and really supports the atmosphere.

On the downside, the build depth feels almost nonexistent. I played using basically one skill up to level 20 and never really felt pushed to experiment or rely on synergies. If synergies exist, they are not clearly communicated. The game is not very clear about what each mastery (skill tree) really offers. Skill descriptions are too vague, and the naming of masteries and stats is not intuitive. 
From a UI perspective, it is also strange not to have a permanent stats panel when you open the inventory. You have to click on "Details", and even then you do not get a satisfying overall view of your character‚Äôs stats.

Despite these issues with build clarity and depth, Titan Quest II is still an excellent game in my eyes: beautiful, immersive, enjoyable to play, with a fantastic atmosphere and an outstanding soundtrack.

I'll start by saying I am a huge TQ1 fan, and to a lesser degree a GD fan. I think the two mastery system in general is the most fun I ever have with ARPGs, by design it creates hundreds of builds. I have hundreds of hours in TQ1 and I'm sure I'll break one thousand soon enough.

That being said I want to be clear about this, this game is NOT for TQ1 fans. It doesn't mean a TQ1 fan couldn't like it, but in the way Grim Dawn was clearly a TQ spiritual successor this game just isn't. So because of that I'll end it there on the TQ1 comparison, this could of course change, as of writing they ARE adding charms and relics, but it is SO much different for the worse in comparison to TQ1.

So as just a general ARPG how does it stack up? Eh it's ok. I have 3 main reasons I've been consistent on since the early Demo last year that have not been addressed as of the time of this writing.

1. Progression is boring

2. Combat is stiff

3. Skills and attributes.

I've written these 3 points multiple times so I'll be as brief as I can warrant while still trying to get my point across.

1. Progression IS the gameplay loop of an ARPG. In MOST ARPGs you can never really become "the best" version of your build, at least not sub 1k hours per build, maybe more. You theorycraft a build (or use a guide) do X to get the build going, beat Y to test the build, then grind Z to make the build better. Rinse, repeat. This game is in early access yet so I'm trying to be fair with this but man when I say the current skill trees/progression does NOTHING to excite me about the progression loop, it'd be an understatement. 

One of the beautiful things about TQ1 is each layer of your build, for simplicity I'll just say Normal, Epic, Legendary, had depth to it. You wanna create that dual wielding berserker, pick Warfare and by like level 5 you'll see your idea starting to form with clear goals of where to go from there. This game however, since 90% of the power of each skill is hidden in a sub menu, there's none of that. Can you even create a fun dual wielding build (actual auto attack not just having two weapons equipped), no idea because I have no clue what works with dual wielding and what doesn't.

There could be amazing perks that some skills have SPECIFIC to dual wielding but again, there's no clear way to know that without spending WAY too much time in very boring menus. The bright, and inviting skill tree of 1 is replaced with a dull, boring, and hard to actually theorycraft skill tree. 

2. Auto attacking feels bad, casting feels bad, arguably the one ability that felt good has supposedly been nerfed to the ground, and even that would have gotten old regardless. I don't have much to say about this, but just do better. Almost every obvious pick for "best ARPG" has better, and more fluid combat.

3. The meat and potatoes. I have no clue who designed the current skill/progression system but they need to be relocated to another department. So for those unfamiliar with how ARPGs.... and really many RPGs, work it's like this. Invest a point in Skill X, Skill X gets better, normally in the sense of +damage. This game had the revolutionary idea for skill points to just add.... the possibility of giving your skill traits? 

It's awful, unfun, and I'm sure adds to my first point about progression feeling so unfun. I don't understand this direction but think a simple workaround would be something like this, actually let a skills level increase it's effectiveness (i.e. +damage), have nodes like TQ1 and GD that replace the current perk system, allow perks to have level requirements for base skill and qualifiers if necessary (i.e. can't use with X, must have Y equipped). 

On top of that mastery level not adding anything to attributes just feels, again so boring. In TQ1 if you put all points into the bar as it was called you still GOT stronger, albeit in a more "number go up," sort of way. This game there's none of that. So there are 100% level ups where I'm just not progressing at all. 1 point into bar, 2 into a skill I don't get a perk in yet in the higher levels, and 2 points being saved for a later passive. 

I also think the 1 point mastery, 2 active, 2 passive split is awful. Just give people 5 points per level up, let them put it in whatever they want.

Overall I wish this game all the best, I hope these devs prove me wrong and make this game as amazing as it very well could be, but as of right now it fails as a TQ sequel, fails as a good APRG, and just fails to be fun.

It's not enought even for an early axes. The current itemisation is really flat. When I open chest or killing an enemy there is a chance to drop an item with random rarity and random stats. Tast's it. The TQ1 system is also preety shallow, but here there is nothing to do with an item after you found it.

If you found a high tier white base, there is nothing that will help you to improve it. If you found the magic item with one good mod, there could be a white item with higher tier (and damage/defences) that makes you magic item useless. You found a decent rare? There is nothing to improve it and prolongue its utility. After a several levels it will be worse than some normal items.

In my oppinion the itemization at the moment should be the first priority for the developers. At least untill there is at least something.

[b] Rewards [/b]
The rewards from bosses are ok, but there are not that much bosses right now. I am talking mainlty about the semi-secret paths with the chest in the end. They felt like a regular chests that I can see on the fields or roads. So I felt like my attention to details wasn't rewarded enough.

[h3] Can't rationalize yet [/h3]

I actually don't have anything against this game being incomplete as some reviewers - seriously why would you give thumb down for an early release not being complete? - but what I can't get past is the clunkiness and slowness of the game. Moving around with your character is not rewarding - you slowly plod through the landscape, as if through molasses, and when you hit something or cast a spell, it feels as if it the action was in slow-motion. If this is how it stays, I can't really recommend this game to anyone who likes fast(er)-paced gameplay - it feels like watching a YouTube video on 0.8. 

Also, what I don't understand is why would you sink so many developer hours into designing a really, really advanced character creator where you can choose your eyebrows, scars (want them fresh or dated?), and the size of your character's head? Come on, this is top-down RPG - you'll never see your character past the character creator anyway - who cares about this stuff! 

I will come back to this when the development has progressed.
